Five recommended reports from Aftenbladet: How much does a good life cost?
We have handpicked five reports for you.
05 Nov 2019, 05:00 at Stavanger Aftenblad
How much does a good life cost?


More time for play, less time for work.ğŸ“· Find E. VÃ¥ga


Read the case: How much does a good life cost?

Is it possible to halve your income and still live a good life without missing anything? Surprisingly easy, says Nanna Hyldgaard Hansen.
Nanna and her husband lived toddler life and had stressful jobs. Finally, it said stop for both. Something had to be done.
Nanna made a list of things she liked to do. It turned out that a lot of what was on the list was free. Then Nanna had a radical idea: Could the family cut all her expenses by half, so that both she and Lasse could go down to a 50 per cent position? Where does one start, if so?

For over 30 years he has only worked at night: - What would Shellen have been without Egil? And what would Egil have been without Shellen?


- I don't know what other work I could have done. Life at a gas station is perfect for me, says Egil Tveit.ğŸ“· Anders Minge


Read the case: Egil at Shellen

He works when we sleep and sleeps when we work. Nobody has more nights at a gas station than Egil Tveit.
For over 30 years he has been there. Every other week he walks in just before eleven o'clock in the evening, replaces a shirt with red jacket and fleece vest, drops a cup of black coffee and lets his gaze wander through the store. Are the floor mats clean? Does the counter of tempting foods abound? Enough sausages for night hungry ravens?
Egil Tveit knows this life. Because according to bomb-proof sources - ie taxi drivers - he is the one in the region with decidedly longest travel time as a night watchman at a gas station. Since August 1, 1988, he has never worked a single hour during the day.

No one had seen Siw at Easter. Environmental worker PÃ¥l Holden recognized the smell as soon as he opened the door


ğŸ“· Private / Mariken Steen-Forgaard


Read the case: The story of Siw

"This is the story you should never read. Memories were displaced. Journals were closed. House was demolished.
Still, someone stood under a bridge and sang about her. Others dreamed of her, so awkward that they were afraid to sleep.
She was whispered in the canteen. And then one day she was mentioned by chance.
That's how we first heard about Siw. "
Siw was found dead in a municipal residence in Stavanger after Easter 2015.
